titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller (Nelson A.) Gubernatorial records, James Cannon, Series 7
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller Gubernatorial records, James Cannon, Series 7 FA356

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-09-15 00:16:21 -0400.

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller gubernatorial records, James Cannon, Series 7

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller served as governor of New York from January 1, 1959, to December 18, 1973. He was the first person elected to four consecutive four-year terms as a state governor.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into two subseries:
Subseries 1 - Revenue Sharing, 1971-1972 Subseries 2 - Latin American Mission, 1968-1972

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: NOTE TO RESEARCHERS

This series contains the office files of James Cannon. They document official activities in the execution of his duties as a member of Nelson A. Rockefeller's staff. The actions, decisions, and exchanges of information or points of view documented here occurred in the course of proposing and implementing policies for the Rockefeller administration, political campaigns, and/or Rockefeller's personal activities. However, unless a document is specifically addressed to or from Rockefeller, or is referred to in a document addressed to him, it should not be assumed he saw the document or was aware of its existence or substance. Furthermore, researchers should bear in mind that staff files may contain documents or drafts addressed to Rockefeller that were never shown to him.
SCOPE AND CONTENT

This series contains a portion of the files of James Cannon. They were created primarily during Cannon's tenure as an executive assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Cannon worked in the New York State Washington Office in the early 1970s and reported on fiscal and revenue sharing matters in the U.S. Congress. In 1969, Cannon was part of the Governor's staff on the Presidential Mission to Latin America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries primarily concerns Cannon's tenure in Washington, DC, where he attended to fiscal matters before the U.S. Congress on behalf of Governor Rockefeller. Cannon served as a intermediary representing the interests of the Rockefeller administration to the members of the New York State Congressional Delegation. The chronological files that start the subseries deal with the events and circumstances leading up to the passage of the State and Local Fiscal Assistance Act of 1972. Of note in the subseries is Folder 18, which concerns the General Grant Revenue Act of 1971, proposed by New York Congressmen Hugh Carey and Ed Koch.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After several discussions with President Richard Nixon, in 1969 Nelson Rockefeller was appointed to undertake a Presidential Mission to Latin America to consult with the leaders of those republics and determine the needs and conditions there. During the spring and summer of that year, Rockefeller toured 20 Latin American countries. This subseries contains a small sample of the documentation of the mission. Notable in this subseries is correspondence with members of President Nixon's staff, specifically National Security Advisor Henry Kissinger, who monitored the mission from Washington.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Additional extensive materials on the Latin American Mission may be found in the Washington, DC, series in Record Group 4 of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Papers (Boxes 98-201).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, notes, clippings, schedules, background information, telexes to Henry Kissinger at White House, memos from Kissinger, correspondence with Berent Friele, transcripts and remarks, and meeting notes.
